awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a single-mode terahertz free electron lasers for research in materials, physics, chemistry and biology
awd_abstract_narration:
The terahertz frequency range lies at the heart of the electromagnetic spectrum, between the domains of electronics and optics.  An electromagnetic wave with a frequency of one terahertz oscillates one trillion cycles per second?about 1000 times faster than the electromagnetic waves used by cell phones, and 500 times slower than the electromagnetic waves that constitute visible light.  Terahertz electromagnetic waves have been, so far, relatively little used by society because they are hard to generate.  However, that is changing rapidly, propelled by revolutions in optics and electronics.  The UC Santa Barbara Free-Electron lasers are the brightest sources of tunable terahertz radiation in the world. This project will increase the brightness available to users of the UCSB Free-Electron Laser facility by a factor between 100 and 1000.  The upgraded facility will enable fundamental research on the interaction of electromagnetic radiation with electronic materials, molecules, and biological matter. The insights gained from this fundamental research will have important implications for information technology, defense, and biotechnology.  

Terahertz technology is rapidly advancing, with tabletop sources now available that generate peak electric fields in excess of 1 MV/cm (peak power >106 W) in pulses with bandwidths of ~1 THz, and much more compact electronic sources that generate mW powers with sub-kHz linewidths.  An increasing number of fascinating scientific questions and important technological developments require access to tunable terahertz electromagnetic fields with very high spectral brightness, which combine extremely high power and electric field with extremely narrow linewidth.  The major research instrumentation to be developed here will greatly enhance the state of the art in this high-power/narrow-linewidth niche.  The UC Santa Barbara Free-Electron Lasers, which are tunable from 0.24 to 4.5 THz with >1 kW power in few-microsecond pulses, will be enhanced by reducing the linewidth of the emitted radiation to <1 MHz over their entire tuning range while precisely controlling and measuring the frequency of the emitted radiation and enabling ?slicing? of the Free-Electron Laser (FEL) output into a series of pulses with durations variable from ~1 ns to the full few-microsecond pulse duration. The free-electron laser enhancements will enable important new research in condensed matter physics, chemistry and biology by (1) improving the precision and control of several experimental methodologies that have already been developed at the UC Santa Barbara FEL facility, and (2) enabling some experiments that could not previously be envisioned.  This development heavily leverages more than 35 years of infrastructure, investment, institutional commitment, and expertise at UC Santa Barbara.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:  Across the electromagnetic spectrum, increasingly powerful and tunable sources of electromagnetic radiation are driving discovery and innovation touching nearly all fields of science and technology.  Tunable lasers that combine high power and high spectral purity (which we define here as high "brightness") enable unique and powerful studies of matter. Despite remarkable advances over the last 20 years in compact sources of electromagnetic radiation within the "Terahertz gap" centered at about one trillion cycles per second, or 1 terahertz (THz), the Free-Electron Lasers (FELs) at the Institute for Terahertz Science and Technology (ITST) at the University of California at Santa Barbara (UCSB) remain the world's brightest sources of tunable THz electromagnetic radiation.  The UCSB FELs have enabled breakthroughs that could not have occured at any other facility.  For example, more than 90 years after Felix Bloch theoretically derived the mathematical description of the wavelike motion of electron a crystal lattice--now called the Bloch wavefunction-- the UCSB FELs recently enabled the first experimental reconstruction of quantum wavefunctions of electrons in a crystalline solid (see Costello et. al., Nature 599,  57-61 (2021), and associated reporting in Scientific American)).  The UCSB FELs have also enabled rapid and coherent manipulation of electron spins at very high frequencies and magnetic fields (see Takahashi et. al., Nature 489, 409 (2012)), recently enabling the first coherent manipulation of a promising candidate for an optically-addressable molecular quantum bit (Fataftah et. al., Journal of the American Chemical Society, 142, 48, 20400-20408 (2020)).

The two principal outcomes of this award are

1.      The construction of a new FEL with a helical electromagnetic undulator ("helical FEL") has been completed at UCSB's ITST (please see image).  The helical FEL is a large and complex system whose construction has required solving a multitude of hard problems associated with ultrahigh vacuum, relativistic electron beams, visible and terahertz optics, electrothermal management, software, and many delicate mechanical systems.  The helical FEL is designed to be 100-1000 times brighter than existing UCSB FELs at nearly all frequencies between 0.2 and 0.5 THz. 

2.     Demonstration that one can modulate terahertz radiation using commonly-available semiconductors and light emitted from compact and inexpensive (<$25) laser diodes. 

 Broader impacts:    

1.      The record brightness of the helical FEL at sub-THz frequencies will enable unprecedented studies of the dynamics of electron spins at high magnetic fields by researchers at many institutions.  These studies hold great promise for developing molecular quantum bits for enhanced quantum sensing;  evaluating strategies to vastly increase the sensitivity of nuclear magnetic resonance to shed light on the mechanism of protein function in cells and other environments; developing "spintronic" devices that can rapidly process information with much less energy than electronics; and detecting "spinon" excitations that would be a smoking gun for the existence of an elusive and long-sought state of strongly-interacting spins called a quantum spin liquid. The high brightness and spectral purity of the helical FEL will also enable expansion of the recent reconstruction of electron wavefunctions in semiconductors to many other important materials.

2.      In collaboration with a small company called Bridge12, LLC, a new type of "pulse slicer" is being developed for commercialization, based on the demonstration in this award of terahertz modulation using inexpensive laser diodes.  The initial market for these pulse slicers is the international community of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopists. The new pulse slicers will enable the generation of sequences of nanosecond-to-microsecond pulses from gyrotrons, which are fixed-frequency sources of powerful, spectrally-pure sub-THz radiation that are deployed in many NMR facilities worldwide.  At this time, gyrotrons deployed at NMR facilities can not generate such short pulses.  Pulse slicers would open the world of pulsed electron magnetic resonance to these  facilities, greatly increasing the scope of possible scientific investigations.
